title: Cyber Daily: Workers Get State Income Benefits After Cyberattack on German Manufacturer
text:
Like other compensation matters, cybersecurity contingencies could be factored into more labor-union contracts. Ransomware groups in particular often target manufacturers, schools, hospitals and other vital sectors powered by unionized workers.

The growing reliance on hybrid IT infrastructures that support cloud-based applications and a largely remote workforce is creating network security and performance challenges for many enterprises.

Read More

Over 1,000 employees at Eberspächer Gruppe GmbH & Co KG are collecting state income benefits just days after a cyberattack that is preventing them from working, a union representative said.

The company has around 10,000 employees in 28 countries, roughly 4,500 of them in Germany, and specializes in exhaust technology, automotive electronics and thermal systems for cars.

"All systems are out of order. No one is able to work their normal job," said Jürgen Groß, managing director of the trade union IG Metall's office in Esslingen, which negotiated the details of the compensation.

Eberspächer Gruppe called the intrusion an "organized attack" and said its "IT infrastructure was affected." A spokeswoman declined to elaborate on the type of attack.

Normally, it takes three weeks for unions to negotiate payment under the short-time work program, but Eberspächer Gruppe and IG Metall were able to come to an agreement over just a couple of days after the attack, Mr. Groß said.

"If there is a problem like this, we look for solutions. The solution is that people get money," he said.

Cybersecurity

Changeup: Federal prosecutors charged a Minnesota man on Thursday with illegally streaming sports games from sites including Major League Baseball and then attempting to extort the league after he hacked its website. The U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan accused 30-year-old Joshua Streit of operating a website that illegally live-streamed games from professional sports leagues, including Major League Baseball, the National Basketball Association, the National Football League and the National Hockey League.

Mr. Streit faces charges including knowingly accessing a protected computer in furtherance of fraud and sending interstate threats with the intent to extort. A lawyer for Mr. Streit couldn't immediately be identified. (WSJ)

Cyberattack trickles down: Budweiser brewer Anheuser-Busch InBev SA sold more beer at higher prices in the third quarter, as strong demand in South America helped make up for weakness in the U.S, the company's largest market. AB InBev said revenue dropped 0.8% in the U.S., a decline partly blamed on supply chain disruptions that left some of its drinks out of stock. CEO Michel Doukeris pointed to storms in the south and a cyberattack that impacted a big glass supplier. (WSJ)

Regulation

Global regulators back tougher rules to prevent criminals from using crypto. Cryptocurrency firms could be forced to take greater steps to combat money laundering under new guidelines released on Thursday by the Financial Action Task Force, an international body that coordinates government policy on illicit finance. More than three dozen countries are FATF members, including the U.S., China and much of Europe.

The task force called on governments to broaden regulatory oversight of crypto firms and force more of them to take measures such as checking the identities of their customers and reporting suspicious transactions to regulators.

Representatives of the crypto industry criticized the guidelines, saying they would undermine privacy, stifle innovation or simply not work in the context of blockchain and digital-asset technology. (WSJ)

Talent

Next gen: Microsoft plans to seed community colleges across the U.S. with training materials and scholarships to train teachers and students in cybersecurity. The effort, which Microsoft President Brad Smith said will cost tens of millions of dollars, will help fill 250,000 cyber jobs in the next four years. (Reuters)

Enforcement

South Korea extradited a Russian national to Ohio to face charges in a wide-ranging ransomware campaign. Over nearly five years starting in November 2015, so-called Trickbot malware attacked businesses, hospitals, schools and governments, according to the Justice Department. Vladimir Dunaev allegedly coded functions for Trickbot that, among other activities, helped it evade detection tools. An attorney for Mr. Dunaev couldn't immediately be contacted. (Reuters)
